normalised: Okay, let's talk flash sales. You know, those heart-stopping, breath-holding, "O M G, I need it now!" moments that e-commerce sites like Myntra and Ajio throw at us? They're like the online equivalent of finding that perfect, crisp rupee five hundred note tucked away in your old jeans. Score!

unnormalised: But are they really worth all the hype? Do you actually save money, or are you just falling for clever marketing tactics? Think of it like this: Imagine you're craving Hyderabadi biryani. Suddenly, Paradise Restaurant announces a 50% off flash sale on their biryani for the next hour only! Your mouth waters, you practically teleport yourself there, and end up buying enough biryani to feed the entire family, even though you only needed one plate. That's kinda how flash sales work, right?

unnormalised: The thing is, flash sales can be amazing if you're smart about it. They're especially great around festival time, like right before Diwali, when everyone's scrambling for new clothes and electronics. You can snag some serious deals, like that cool new phone you've been eyeing or a gorgeous silk saree from Kanjeevaram.

unnormalised: But here's the catch: impulsive buying! Don't get caught up in the frenzy and buy something you don't actually need. That beautiful handloom kurta might be 70% off, but if it's three sizes too big, it's just going to sit in your closet gathering dust. Remember that time Priya bought 5 pairs of shoes in a flash sale, only to realize they were all slightly uncomfortable? Lesson learned!

unnormalised: So, the next time you see a flash sale pop up, take a deep breath, channel your inner chill Delhiite, and ask yourself: Do I REALLY need this? Is this a good price, even without the discount? And most importantly, will I actually use it?
